docs.lead_paragraph: Residents of the District of Columbia and New Jersey are more sedentary than Kansans, according to a survey by the Federal Centers for Disease Control that also said that North Carolinians are fatter than Montanans. The telephone survey, part of a continuing project on behavioral risk factors for health, covered adults in the District of Columbia, Delaware, Indiana, Kansas, Kentucky, Montana, New Jersey, North Carolina and Ohio. Other states were covered in a March report and more will be covered in future reports, the agency said recently in its Morbidity and Mortality Weekly Report.

headline.main: ST. LOUIS BEARS BRUNT OF HEAT WAVE AS U.S. TOLL RISES

byline.original: Special to the New York Times

docs.lead_paragraph: For more than two weeks a deadly heat wave with temperatures in the upper 90's and low 100's has kept the daytime sky here a sickly pastel blue. Forty-two people in the St. Louis area have died from heat-related causes as of today, accounting for more than one-third of the national heat death toll of 123. Since the heat wave began, the weather has been blamed for at least 29 deaths in Missouri; 34 in Kentucky, 27 in Illinois; 12 in Georgia, and smaller numbers in North Carolina, Indiana, Ohio, Arkansas, New York, Tennessee and Maryland. Four elderly residents of a Chicago nursing home died after the building's air conditioning system failed in Friday's 100-degree temperatures. Deputy Health Commissioner Phillip Davis said it was ''a reasonable assumption'' that the deaths were heat-related.

headline.main: IDEA OF IDEAL WEIGHT SHOULD BE FORGOTTE, MEDICAL WRITER SAYS

docs.lead_paragraph: People should abandon the concept of an ''ideal weight'' because it is based on inconsistent data, an article in the current issue of The Journal of the American Medical Association says. The recommendation comes from Thomas R. Knapp of the graduate school of education and human development at the University of Rochester, Dr. Knapp, whose advanced degree is in education, suggested that ''ideal weight'' was a slippery concept and observed: ''Perhaps the best one can hope to do is to study the very light and the very heavy with extreme care, using various indicators of mortality, morbidity and psychological well-being, and switch the focus from 'ideal weights' to 'dangerous weights.' ''Unit-of-analysis problems are tricky, the conversion of weightfor-height measures into measures of obesity are highly controversial and the data will never be sufficiently clean to warrant the serious use of tables that satisfy both methodological and substantive concerns.''
